description: Richardson extrapolation is a classical numerical analysis technique that systematically eliminates leading-order error terms by combining estimates at different step sizes (or in our case, noise levels). It is mathematically equivalent to polynomial extrapolation but provides a more structured approach.

The key insight is that if the error expands as a power series in λ, then taking appropriate linear combinations of measurements at different λ values can cancel successive error terms. This is the basis for many high-precision numerical methods.
In the QEM context, Richardson extrapolation provides a systematic way to improve ZNE accuracy by using measurements at geometrically-spaced noise levels (e.g., λ = 1, 2, 4 or λ = 1, 3, 5).
how_it_works: Assume the expectation value has an error expansion: ⟨O⟩(λ) = ⟨O⟩₀ + c₁λ + c₂λ² + c₃λ³ + ...
Measure at noise levels λ₁ < λ₂ < ... < λₙ (often geometric: λₖ = λ₁ · rᵏ⁻¹).
Combine measurements with weights chosen to cancel the first n-1 error terms.
The result has error O(λⁿ) instead of O(λ).

key_equations.label: General Richardson weights
key_equations.latex: \langle O \rangle_0 = \sum_{i=1}^{n} w_i \langle O \rangle_i, \quad \text{where } \sum_i w_i = 1 \text{ and } \sum_i w_i \lambda_i^k = 0 \text{ for } k=1,...,n-1

advantages: Systematic error reduction: order-n Richardson has O(λⁿ) bias
Weights can be computed analytically for specific scale factors
Generalizes to multivariate case (Layerwise Richardson Extrapolation)
disadvantages: Assumes power-series error expansion (may not hold for all noise types)
Optimal scale factors depend on the error expansion coefficients
High-order Richardson can amplify statistical noise significantly
